loans.use: Retail Sale of Household Products

loans.name: Dora Bernadina

texts.en:
Dora Bernadina H. J. is a member of the community bank, Tarpuy, a Quechuan word meaning, “to sow or to plant.” Dora lives in Ayacucho with her husband; they have 6 children ages 35-22. Dora currently works with her neighbor selling bread.

With her loan of 1200 soles, Dora will purchase ingredients for the bread including seasonings, flour and sugar. Dora’s dream is to save enough money to purchase her own oven to bake bread and have her own business. She also hopes that her children continue their education, earn their degrees and become professionals.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for the bread including seasonings, flour and sugar.

loans.name: Basti

texts.es: Su dedicación a la venta de productos de belleza lo hace por su hijo. La señora Basti es consultora de belleza de una línea cosmética por catálogo muy conocida a nivel nacional, ella vende estos productos por los diferentes alrededores de la ciudad de Pucallpa, así como también es la encargada de buscar personas que quieren trabajar con ella en la venta de estos productos. Esta labor la realiza desde hace 2 años, y lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que conoce mucha gente, le es rentable porque cuenta con una clientela selecta, por lo que le va muy bien. A razón de que tiene un negocio rentable, quiere comprar más de estos productos,  así como también adquirir una vitrina para mostrarlos y que estén protegidos.
texts.en:
She makes her living selling beauty products for the sake of her son. Mrs. Basti is a beauty consultant for a well-known national line of catalog cosmetics. She sells these products in different areas of the city of Pucallpa, as well as finding persons who want to work for her selling the products. She has been doing this for two years, and what she likes about her work is meeting so many people. It is profitable because she deals with a select clientele, so it is going well for her. Because she has a profitable business, she wants to buy more products, as well as to acquire a display case to both protect and display them.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a larger quantity of beauty products as well as a display case to display them

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina A. sells fish, which she buys from fishermen, and then brings them home for processing and preservation. She then sends them to the market for sale at Atonkwa near Elmina. Dina has made her way through a junior high education. She is married and has 4 children. Her husband is a trader.

Dina has been selling fish since 1998. She assists her husband in meeting the family's financial needs. Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy fish in larger quantities for processing and sale. She hopes to use the new profits to reinvest in fish sales to expand her business.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy fish in larger quantities for processing and sale.

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi: Chị Lê Thị Lệ, 41 tuổi ở huyện Kim Động. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 1997 . Sau khi tham gia Quỹ với số vốn vay được chị đã mạnh dạn đầu tư mua thêm đất mở rộng quy mô trồng trọt và chăn nuôi của gia đình. Nhờ sự cần cù, chịu khó, sau 11 năm vay vốn từ Quỹ, hiện nay gia đình chị đã có 2 sào bưởi các loại chủ yếu là bưởi Diễn và bưởi năm roi cho thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay với mức vốn là 15.000.000 để đầu tư mua thêm phân bón và cây giống.
texts.en:
Mrs. L. Thi L. is 41 years old. She lives at the province of Kim Dong. She joined TYM Fund in 1997. After joining the fund, she has borrowed funds to buy more land for growing and raising livestock. After 11 years of hard work, her family now has 2 sao of pomelo trees (approximately 360 square meters). Her trees bring her an income of 2,000,000 VND per month. She would like to borrow 15,000,000 VND to invest in fertilizer and seedlings.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Growing

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi A. is married and has 5 dependents. She has received no formal education. Esi sells yams and palm oil at the Jukai market near Cape Coast, which she has done for about 10 years. Her husband is a farmer.

Esi uses her income to help her husband pay rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Esi will use the loan to increase her capital to buy food supplies in larger quantities for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esi plans to reinvest for the expansion of her sales of food supplies. The containers beside her are some in which she keeps the oil she produces before sale.

loans.use: to increase her capital to buy food supplies

loans.name: Angélica

texts.es:
Angélica es socia del Bancomunal Avancemos Juntas.
Angélica es conviviente, tiene 39 años, cuatro hijos, de 22, 19, 16 y 13 años, los dos mayores trabajan y los dos  últimos están en la escuela estatal.
Angélica  desde joven trabajo para mantener  a sus hermanos por  eso no pudo estudiar nada; tuvo sus hijos y se dedico a cuidarlos, pero la necesidad  era mucha   se puso a  vender verduras, no le iba nada  bien,   junto un dinero y  decidió cambiar de giro, puso una tienda  de abarrotes.  
Angelica  necesita un préstamo de préstamo de 800 soles, para la compra de arroz, azúcar, leche, harina. 
Desde que está en Finca, ha crecido en el negocio, tiene más  capital y más mercadería, aprendió a no gastarse el capital, sacar su ganancia y ahorrar. 
El sueño de angélica es abrir otra bodega, y vender productos de buena calidad.
texts.en:
Angélica is a member of the Community Bank, "Avancemos Juntas" ["We Make Progress Together"]. Angélica is a common law wife and is 39 years old. She has 4 children- a 22 year old, a 19 year old, a 16 year old, and a 13 year old. The two older children work and the two youngest are in public school. Since she was young, Angélica has worked to support her siblings. For this reason, she couldn't study anything; she had children and dedicated herself to caring for them. But when it was necessary she began to sell vegetables, but nothing good was coming. With her money, she changed direction and opened a grocery store. Angélica needs a loan of 800 soles to buy rice, sugar, milk, and flour. Since she became a member of Finca, her business has grown and she has more capital and merchandise. She has learned not to spend the capital, but to take her earnings and save. Angélica's dream is to open another store and to sell high quality products.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, milk and flour

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: Michael Kachagwa is a Tanzanian micro entrepreneur. He is married and has three school-going children. He runs a hardware shop at the Buguruni ward in Dar es Salaam. He sells various items including color and cement. He purchases the items from the wholesale shops at the Kariakoo shopping center and retails to customers at Buguruni. The income generated from the business is used to meet the daily needs of his family. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 800,000 to boost up his hardware business.

loans.use: To expand his hardware business

loans.name: Lemalie

texts.en: Lemalie V., 35, is married with 6 children.  She has 1 year of experience in the food stall business. She sells to the general public 7 days per week. She has had 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~250 USD).  SPBD loans are Lemalie’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase pots, sack of taros, bunch of bananas, chemical weeds

loans.name: Shelah Group

texts.en:
Shelah is the group leader of Shelah group. There are four members in this group. Each of them would like to receive money for her/his business. The total of their group loan is 40000 Afghani.

Kamalah wants to take a loan for her sewing business. She wants a new machine for her business. Shelah wants to take a loan for her business of embroidery. She wants to buy necessary materials for her business. And Hasena wants to take a loan for bead work. She wants buy necessary materials for her business. Amena wants to take a loan for her business of tailoring. She wants to expand her business. 

 With this loan they can make their businesses bigger and support their families and make a better future for themselves and for their families in future.

loans.use: expand their businesses and buy necesssary materials

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is a 34-year-old simple businesswoman who is married to Roderick B., who works as a farmer in their village. They live peacefully in the village of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela. The couple has been blessed with six children. Reymart is the eldest, 16 years old, and he is in fourth year high school, next is Rachelle who is 13 years old, third is Reymund, 12 years old, Roderick is fourth, and is 10 years old, fifth is Rovie who is 7 years old and Rhea, the youngest is only 5 months old. Marites is happy to have a big family because she has a principle in life that “the more children you have, the merrier the family is”.

Marites is engaged in selling different commodities that serves as her source of income. She has a small table located in front of their house where she retails her goods. Before, she was selling vegetables and barbeque but she thought of changing her vending into bread, soft drinks, food seasonings and other commodities.

She is planning to have a small store to be able to make her vending convenient and comfortable for her customers. In this regard, she is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 to be used in buying more items to sell so that her income will increase. Thus she will be able to have funds to build her store.

So far, she is earning a net income of 200 pesos daily. She really hopes that she will have more capital to make her business grow. Marites is willing to sacrifice for the benefit of her children, especially now that her eldest will shortly enter high school.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell

loans.name: Kamolidin

texts.ru:
Ашуров Камолидин, 1988 года рождения, холост. Он студент юридического факультета, у него любимое дело. Камолидин производит и продает национальный табак - «Нос». Этот бизнес он унаследовал от своего отца. Вот уже 5 лет у него собственная лавка, где он продает свой продукт. Ему в этом деле помогает старший брат.  
 Он хочет получить займ в сумме 1000 сомони сроком на 6 месяцев для закупа табака.
texts.en:
Kamolidin A. was born in 1988 and is single. He is a law student, and he has a favorite activity. Kamolidin makes and sells traditional tobacco, called Nose. He inherited this business from his father. He has had his own shop for 5 years in which he sells this product. His older brother helps him. He wants to take out a loan for 1000 somoni to buy tobacco.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying tobacco

loans.name: Dib

texts.en: Dib S., 30, is married and lives with her husband in the Batambong province. Selling vegetables and pork, she makes US$25 in revenue each day and her husband works construction making US$7 each day. Dib S. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase both construction materials, and vegetables and pork to sell. She sees these purchases as a good investment to expand her business and she is confident it will increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials, vegetables and pork.

loans.name: Luz

texts.es: Luz es una mujer muy empeñosa en su rol como esposa y madre de 4 hijos, quienes son su mayor tesoro y a quienes trata de brindarles los mejores cuidados. Junto a su esposo, tener una casa propia donde habitar en familia fue algo que consiguió con mucho sacrificio. Apoyar a su pareja en los gastos del hogar fue determinante para ella, ya que trabajó en diversas actividades, pero desde hace 6 años se dedica a la administración de los motocarros que lograron comprar para alquilarlos a las personas que realizan transporte público. Debido a la delincuencia que hay su zona, cada vez que alquila uno de sus vehículos trata de fijarse muy bien en cada una de las personas que le soliciten el alquiler. Otra de las actividades que realiza es estar pendiente de los mantenimientos mecánicos de sus motocarros cada fin de mes para que estén permanentemente en óptimas condiciones. Los ingresos que recibe diariamente son de gran beneficio para su hogar, y por tal motivo, Luz desea adquirir otras movilidades para incrementar sus ganancias. Este es su 13avo crédito con Microfinanzas PRISMA y en este tiempo ha trabajado con suma responsabilidad, al igual que sus compañeras de banco comunal. Los 1500 soles que solicita los invertirá en la compra de repuestos para uno de sus motocarros que necesita reparaciones para seguir con su normal funcionamiento.
texts.en:
Luz is a hard-working woman in her role as wife and mother of 4 children who are her greatest treasure and for whom she tries to provide more. With her husband, they have a home of their own which was obtained with much sacrifice. Supporting her partner with the household’s expenses was a deciding factor in her current occupation, as she had worked in various arenas before deciding to dedicate herself to public transportation 6 years ago. They managed to buy some vehicles that they rent to people who are in the transportation business. Due to the delinquency that abounds in her zone, each time she leases out one of her vehicles she examines each potential renter very carefully. Another activity she realizes is tending to the mechanical repairs and maintenance of her motocars at month-end to make sure they are operating at their best. The daily income she generates is very beneficial to her family and, for this reason, Luz would like to acquire more vehicles to increase revenue. This is her 13th loan with Microfinanzas PRISMA and, over this time, she has worked very responsibly like her other colleagues at the cooperative bank. She will invest the 1,500 soles she is requesting into repairs for one of her motocars that needs some work in order to continue to run.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase replacement parts for her motocar.

loans.name: Aladji

texts.fr: Aladji M. est âgé de 32 ans, marié, et père 2 enfants. il est menuisier à Adeta. Aladji exerce ce métier depuis 3 ans. Il souhaite avec ce crédit acheter des outils de travail notamment du bois pour l’exécution de ses œuvres.
texts.en:
Aladji M., age 32, is married and the father of 2 children. He's been a furniture maker in Adeta for 3 years. He wishes to use this loan to buy work tools, in particular wood to realize his artworks.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy work tools and wood

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
"My sari-sari store has an income of PHP 500-1000 daily and I have 2 piglets for fattening that cost PHP 1,800 per piglet", says Jenny P., a CEVI client from Sto Niño, South Cotabato.  Jenny has three children and her eldest will be 12 years old this year. She started a sari-sari store in 2005 and a piggery in 2007.

She is requesting a CEVI loan of PHP 8,000 which she will use to purchase assorted groceries and feeds. The loan will really help her get a good handle on the growing finances of her businesses.

loans.use: To purchase assorted groceries and pig feeds.

loans.name: Ysabel

texts.en:
Ysabel is a member of the Hope village bank. She is 51 years old and has three children. Her eldest is married and her other two are 30 and 21 years old.

Ysabel sold groceries from a cart for many years in front of a market but the police ousted her. She was forced to go to another market where she now sells breakfast on the corner with the help of her daughter. They get up at 2 a.m. in order to prepare quinwa (a grain like rice) and soybean juices, milk, punch, and different kinds of sandwiches. She sells sandwiches with avocado, chicken, and egg. She estimates that she sells 400 breakfasts each week.

Every fifteen days Ysabel takes one day to rest. Since she joined FINCA she feels more secure because she is able to buy a sufficient amount of materials for her business.

Ysabel needs a loan of 3,000 soles to buy sugar, milk, oil, quinwa and soy for the preparation of the breakfasts. Her dream is to put a roof on her house along with doors and windows because she is very cold in the winter.

loans.use: To buy sugar, milk, oil, quinwa and soy for the preparation of breakfasts

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian sells cooked food and drinks to take care of her family's needs and her children's education. She is 43 years old and married with seven children. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more foodstuff to cook and sell and drinks as well. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Nurbubu's Group

texts.en:
Nurbubu is the leader of this group. She is 50 years old and has raised three children. Her eldest son works at a police station. Her middle daughter is married and her younger daughter is a college student. Nurbubu and her husband are, by their nature, very active people. Therefore, Nurbubu prefers a noisy and busy daily routine to the quietness of being at home. They sell foodstuffs in a small shop. 

According to them, it is always possible to set up a business.  In the beginning, Nurbubu did not have a container or a building to use when she wanted to start selling. So she and her husband made a small space right inside their house for their shop.  Long ago, Nurbubu already had experience selling dishes in a big market. This was an incentive for her to open a shop at home after her marriage. Investing just $45 in this undertaking, Nurbubu now earns three times as much on a monthly basis. This very same shop has given Nurbubu an opportunity to educate her children and build a new house. Now Nurbubu hopes that by using this loan she will be able to purchase more goods to enrich the assortment and increase the turnover.  Nurbubu plans to complete the building of their new house, see their son married and build a shed for keeping cattle.  

Nurbubu’s partners are Nazgul, Kanitat and Ramis.  Nazgul, 31, has three children, all of whom are school students. Her husband works as a policeman. Nazgul is engaged in raising cattle and selling milk. Nazgul needs a loan to buy a cow.

Kanitat, 47, is a mother of three children. She is occupied with animal husbandry, selling milk and also needlework. Kanitat needs this loan to cover expenses related to harvesting wheat. 

Ramis, 18, is single. Despite his young age, he and his brother, 17, already take care of his family, which consists of his mother and a five-year-old sister.  Ramis raises cattle and sells milk.  He needs this loan to plant wheat and purchase fuel.  He has decided to try farming and if everything goes well, become a farmer.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to enrich the assortment and increase the turnover

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 39 years-old and married with three children aged between three and 15 years. All her children go to school. Rose resides and owns a two room house where she lives with six people. Rose also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water.

Rose has a stall selling charcoal in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business for four years and with Kiva partner MCDT for eight years. This would be her twentieth loan. She doesn’t pay rent for her business premises but pays monthly market dues. Rose sells both retail and wholesale. She buys her charcoal from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala, and incurs transportation costs. Her challenges include transportation costs and increasing charcoal prices. Rose plans to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. Rose aspires to see her business grow stronger and to eventually sell only wholesale.

loans.use: To buy charcoal.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
"Having many children is not easy. I need to double my time working if I’m to support all their needs, especially their education," said Erlinda S.. She is now 58 years of age and married to Mr. Benjamin S. who is a farmer and already 65 years old. The couple is blessed with eight children. Only one of them is still studying.

Erlinda sells her vegetables and fruit in their village, roaming around the village by going house to house. Though her business is tiring, she does not mind it because she knows that she needs to become strong if she is to succeed.

In connection with that, Erlinda wants to borrow Php 7,000 from Kiva lenders as additional capital for her vending business. If her requested loan is granted, she will buy more vegetables and fruit to sell.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Angella

texts.en:
Angella is 42 years old and married with six children, aged between 15 and 23 years. All of her children go to school. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she is staying with four people. Angella takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water, and gets three meals a day. She doesn’t incur transport costs to and from shopping as she buys from her place of work in Nakawa market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city. She works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala.

Angella works seven days a week. She receives an average of 35 customers a day and sells to all categories of people, both in wholesale and retail. She has a stall selling bananas in Nakawa Market. Her major business challenges are thieves and the ever-increasing prices of bananas due to persistent drought in many villages of Uganda. She has been in this business for over ten years and with MCDT for eight years, currently servicing her twentieth loan. Besides this banana business, she also sells beer at her home. Angella joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was easy to work with. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas and crates of beer. She is aspiring to go to the villages to sell directly.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas and crates of beer

loans.name: Nun

texts.en:
Mrs. Nun C. is 60 years old and her husband, Mr. Ret Toun, is 66 years old. They live along national road number one about 35 kilometers from Phnom Penh. The couple was married in 1965 and has five children: three sons and two daughters. Four of their children are married and live outside the family house and the other is a garment factory worker. Though the couple is elderly, they are still strong enough to work. 

Nun and her husband are farmers. They grow rice on their farmland in the village. Farming is the main business for supporting themselves, so Nun is requesting her first loan of $300 to purchase fertilizer, oil fuel and pesticides to use on her rice farm.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, oil and pesticides for her farming business.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem P., 30, is married with three school-aged children. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband and children. To make a living, she is employed at a Korean food restaurant in the town, earning an income of US $2 per day. The family is also assisted mainly by her husband, who is employed as a police officer and who looks after the safety of the people who visit Angkor Wat Temple. He is able to earn an income of US $7 per day to help cover the family expenses. P. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, P. is asking for a loan of US $600 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. This loan will help her family to cut back on public transportation services. This is her second loan from CREDIT MFI, Kiva’s partner. P. is pictured with her husband and one of her children.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for her husband to commute to work

loans.name: Natividad's Group

texts.en:
Natividad C. is from the village of San Miguel. She is 59 years old. Natividad is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Natividad C.'s Group.

Natividad is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Natividad owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. Natividad has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Natividad joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Natividad has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Natividad is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Natividad from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the group’s businesses. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand inventory and product variety.

loans.name: God Can Make It Group

texts.en:
Rebecca G. W. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called 'God Can Make It'. She is 52 years old and is married with 2 children aged 18 and 30 years old; their educational levels are 10th grade and a high school graduate. She also cares for a nephew, a niece and a grandchild. She could not continue her education through 8th grade due poverty; she had to leave school to fend for her younger brothers, because their father had died.

Rebecca and her family live in the Zayzay community in Paynesville, but she sell in the Red-light market which is the biggest market in Paynesville, Liberia. Rebecca’s business is the sale of 'fufu' (a locally made Liberian dish of cassava). She has been running this business for more than 34 years and hopes to get involved in the real estate business.

Rebecca started by selling children's clothes and her capital, 1000 Liberian Dollars, was given to her by her husband. She sells clean 'fufu' and talks to customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Rebecca needs this loan to add to her capital to improve her business. She dreams of giving her children a better education and building a house for her family in the future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Rebecca is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more fufu for resale

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth N. Makokha is 38 years old, married with three children, living in Kwirare Busia District. She used to be a farmer planting subsistence crops that were not generating enough income. In 1993, Elizabeth went into the fish business with the aim of generating enough income to sustain her family.

Being in this business for more than fifteen years and having learnt about KMET's loan system that works only with determined groups, Elizabeth has seen the need for expanding her business by increasing her stock to ensure enough income for economic sustainability.

She would like to get a loan worth Ksh.20,000 to achieve this and also her future plans for economic development.

loans.use: to increase her stock and expand the business

loans.name: Gie Batuyaay Group

texts.fr: je suis Florence D., responsable du GIE Batuyaay de l'écovillage de Mlomp, en Casamance, Sénégal; Je suis mariée et mère de cinq enfant qui vont tous à l'école. nous venons avec mes amies, demander un financement auprès de Kiva, pour mener des activités génératrices de revenus dans notre écovillage, qui il faut le dire, a déja eu des groupes qui ont reçu un financement de votre institution. Nous voulons commercialiser les produits qui sont exploités dans nos forets et qui sont très recherchés dans les grandes villes comme par exemple l'huiles de myrrhe, de palmiste et de palme, des fruits sauvages qui sont aussi bien consommés dans les villes et surtout des poissons et crevettes séchés qui sont produits par nos maris qui sont des pêcheurs. Nous pensons qu'avec les bénéfices, nous pourront soutenir nos enfants qui sont entrain d'étudier dans les grandes villes.
texts.en:
I am Florence D., responsible for the Batuyaay GIE (Groupement d’Intérêt Economique) of Casamance in Sénégal. I am married and the mother of five children, all going to school. My friends and I are requesting a loan from Kiva, to conduct revenue-generating activities in our eco-village. I should mention that other groups in our village have already been granted loans by your institution. We want to commercialise products from our forests which are in high demand in large towns, for example: myrrh oil, palm oil, palm kernel oil, wild fruit that are also popular in towns, and above all the dried fish and shrimp produced by our fishermen husbands. We believe that with the earnings obtained, we will be able to support our children who are attending big city schools.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy forest and seafood products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of corn to make gruel

loans.name: Pedrito

texts.en:
Pedrito A. is from the village of Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. He is 56 years old. Pedrito is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Pedrito owns a retail flower and candle business in the local community. Pedrito has been engaged in his business for over six years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Pedrito joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pedrito has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Pedrito is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Pedrito from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Marina

texts.es:
LA SRA. MARINA ESTA CASADA VIVE EN LA LOCALIDAD D. EL TORNO DISTANTE A 40 KM D. LA CIUDAD D. SANTA CRUZ, SU ACTIVIDAD ES LA VENTA D. ROPA D. FORMA AMBULANTE, SU ESPOSO TIENE LA OCUPACION CHOFER PROFESIONAL, EN LA LINEA D. TRANSPORTE EL TORNO - SANTA CRUZ, TIENE 3 HIJOS EN EDAD ESCOLAR, SU DOMICILIO ESTA UBICADO EN EL BARRIO 6 D. MAYO, SU DESEO  ES PODER RECUPERAR SU CAPITAL YA QUE POR UNA ENFERMEDAD SE DESCAPITALIZO  Y REDUCIO SU CAPITAL A LA MITAD, YA QUE POR LOS GASTOS UTILIZADOS EN LA CURA, TRATAMIENTO Y SUS MEDICAMENTOS, YA QUE SU SALUD D. PRONTO SE DETERIORO,  Y TUVIERON QUE INTERVENIRLA QUIRURGICAMENTE, FUE DURO PARA ELLA PERO SE RECUPERO Y CON EL DINERO DEL CREDITO COMPRARA MERCADERIA.

POR TAL MOTIVO ELLA HA SOLICITADO A NUESTRA INSTITUCION , EL APOYO FINANCIERO PARA REPONERSE D. TAL PERCANCE.
 
LA SRA. MARINA ESTA MUY AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Sra. Marina is married and lives in the town of El Torno, which is located 40km away from the city of Santa Cruz. She sells clothing as a street vendor. Her husband is a professional chauffeur who provides transportation services between El Torno and Santa Cruz. Marina has three school age children. Her home is located in the May 6th neighborhood.

Marina hopes to recoup her business losses after an illness wiped out half of her business capital, which was used to pay for treatment and medicines. Her health quickly deteriorated and required that she undergo immediate surgery. Now that she is better, she faces difficulty with her business and must rely on credit to acquire merchandise. For this reason, she has requested assistance from Emprender in order to secure financing that will help her recover from this mishap. Marina is extremely grateful to both Emprender and Kiva for demonstrating their confidence in her by providing this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Vidal

texts.es:
El Sr. Vidal P. tiene 38 años de edad, esta casado con la Sra. Teresa hace 15 años, tienen 4 hijos, viven en una Villa llamado Moreira de la ciudad de Coronel Oviedo hace mas de cinco años. 
Don Vidal comenzó siendo ayudante de albañil desde pequeño, aprendió el oficio siendo independiente hace 16 años,  ahora es Oficial de Obras trabajando también con firmas constructoras.
Su trabajo es el sustento de su familia a quien educa con los valores de Honestidad, responsabilidad, sencillez y solidaridad.
Comenta que es difícil conseguir apoyo crediticio para su oficio por lo agradece a Fundación Paraguaya por ofrecerle la oportunidad y de esta manera poder mejorar el nivel de su trabajo, ya que con el crédito comprara herramientas (carretilla y mezcladora)para su grupo de trabajo en un asentamiento en construcción de varias viviendas a su cargo.
texts.en:
Vidal P. is 38 years old. He has been married to Teresa for fifteen years. They have four children. They have lived in a town named Moreira in Coronel Oviedo for more than five years. Mr. Vidal has been a builder's assistant since he was young. He began working independently sixteen years ago. He also now works as a foreman for construction firms. Vidal's work supports his family, who he teaches the values of honesty, responsibility, simplicity, and solidarity. He says it is difficult to get credit support for his business, which is why he is grateful to Paraguaya Foundation for giving him this opportunity to be able to improve the level of his work. With this loan, he will be able to buy tools (a wheelbarrow and a mixer) for his team working at a settlement under construction, where they are responsible for building multiple homes.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying tools (wheelbarrow and mixer)

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria es socia del Banco Comunal Fe.
Maria es casada, tiene 53 años y 2 hijos, Maria vende comida en la puerta de su casa, actividad que realiza todos los días, además vende ropa en las diferentes ferias de la región.
Maria necesita un préstamo de 1800 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de ropa.
Los sueños de Maria son educar a su hijo y nieto, mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Maria is a member of the Faith Community Bank. She is married, 53 years old and has two children. Maria sells food in the doorway of her house. She does this every day. Also she sells clothes at various markets in the region. Maria needs a loan of 1800 soles, money that she will use to buy clothes. Maria dreams include providing an education for her son and grandchild. She also dreams of improving her business.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes.

loans.name: Enedina

texts.es:
Enedina pertenece al Banco Comunal Granito de Mostaza, Enedina es conviviente, tiene 49 años y 4 hijos, Enedina elabora helados y hace algunos meses adquirió su segunda congeladora, sus ventas los realiza en las diferentes ferias de la región, además vende golosinas, frutas y de las ferias compra quesos, huevo, productos que vende en el mercado local. Lo que mas le gusta de su Banco Comunal son las capacitaciones de cómo mejorar relaciones de familia, aprendió a ser puntual y cumplida. Su préstamo será invertido en la compra de azúcar. 
Los sueños de Enedina son que sus hijos culminen sus estudios y sean profesionales, implementar su heladería con mas maquinas.
texts.en:
Enedina, 49, is a member of the "Granito de Mostaza" (Mustard Seed) communal bank. She lives with her life partner and four children. Enedina makes frozen treats and a few months ago acquired a second freezer. Her sales take place in various area markets; she also sells sweets and fruits and buys cheese and eggs at these markets to then bring back to sell in her local market. What she likes best about her communal bank is the training sessions aimed at improving family relations; she learned how to be punctual and how to follow through on things. She will use the loan to buy sugar. Enedina's dreams are that her children finish their studies and become professionals and to equip her ice-cream shop with more machinery.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar.

loans.name: Juan De La Cruz

texts.es:
El Sr. Juan A. , es casado y vive en casa propia. 
El cuenta con una despensa que es uno de los fuentes de ingresos para familia, ademas trabaja en un tambo que tiene en su casa con criás y lecheras.
Se dedica a dichos rubros hace mas de 10 años,   ademas realiza ventas de verduras en su camioneta por los barrios aledaños a su domicilio.
A la fecha el señor Juan ha retirado solicitado el préstamo para la compra de mercaderías para su negocio como arroz, enlatados, enbutidos, golosinas, frutas y verduras.
texts.en:
Juan A. is married and lives in his own house. He owns a store that is one of his family’s sources of income; he also works a dairy farm on his property where he has calves and dairy cows. He has been in these lines of work for over 10 years. He also drives his truck around the neighborhoods near his home selling vegetables. To date, Juan has taken out a loan to buy merchandise for his store such as: rice, canned goods, cured meats, sweets, fruits and vegetables.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruits, vegetables, canned goods, cured meats, sweets, etc.

loans.name: Las Manzanas Group

texts.es:
El grupo las Manzanas está integrado por Catalina P., Emelina P. y  Rolando José ellos son provenientes de Masaya. La coordinadora del grupo es la señora P. quien desde hace 30 años se dedica a realizar sopas y  arroz de leche. En la actualidad desea introducirse en el destace de cerdo, ya que este le generaría mayores ganancias es por ello que con el préstamo piensa comprar cerdo y materia prima.

Mientras Emelina P. realiza tortillas y nacatamales desde hace tres años y Rolando José P.  es comerciante de frutas desde hace dos años.
texts.en:
The Las Manzanas ("The Apples") Group is made up of Catalina P., Emelina P., and Rolando José, who are all from Masaya. The group's coordinator is Ms. P., who has been making soups and rice pudding for the last 30 years. Now, she hopes to get started in the business of butchering pigs, as this would create more income. With this loan, she plans to buy pigs and raw materials. The other group members are Emelina P., who has worked for the last three years making tortillas and nacatamales [a food that is similar to tamales, made of corn and meat steamed in banana leaves], and Rolando José P., who has been a fruit-seller for two years.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy pigs, vegetables, meat, bone, rice, milk, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Juan Ramon

texts.es:
Juan Ramon de 33 años de edad es casado con la Sra. Rosa Natalia Amador con quien tiene 2 niñas: Natalia de 10 años estudiando 5to grado de primaria y Crystel de 2 añitos. Juan Ramon trabaja para el Hospital Asuncion de Juigalpa desde hace 10 años, desempeñandose como  responsable de almacen medico. 

Esta solicitando  refinanciamiento su 11vo credito con el objetivo de levantar 2 paredes y lograr tener un anexo para su casa y brindar mayor comodidad a su familia.  Cabe señalar que el credito anterior fue beneficiado con el fondo kiva y logro instalar la energia electrica a su cuarto y levantar una pared.  

El mayor sueño que tiene es que sus hijas estudien y poder brindarle las condiciones necesarias para que crezcan en un ambiente agradable.
texts.en:
Juan Ramon, 33, and his wife, Sra. Rosa Natalia Amador, have 2 daughters: Natalia, 10, a fifth-year student at a local elementary school and Crystel, 2. Juan Ramon has worked for the Hospital Asuncion de Juigalpa for 10 years. He is responsible for the hospital's medical supply stores. Juan Ramon is applying for his 11th loan. He will use the loan to put up 2 walls and finish building a room on his house, a project that he wants to do so that his family can live more comfortably. He says that, thanks to the last loan that he received from Kiva, he was able to put up one wall and install electricity in the room. Juan Ramon's greatest wishes are that his daughters go to school and that they get everything they need to grow up in a safe and happy environment.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finish addition to house.

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Mrs. Leng K., age 64, is a single mother of six children, all of whom are already married and are employed at different occupations. Most of her children have provided their income to meet the family's expenses. Leng K. is a domestic rice trader who owns many plots of farmland next to her house. On her land, she plants various crops to earn a living. 

Leng K. has been planning to construct a new house on another part of her village land for her married children to live in; however, she cannot achieve her goal because she lacks the necessary funds. To help with this, Leng K. has decided to take out a loan in the amount of $1100 to add to her savings in order to build a new house. Mrs. Leng K. was not available when the photo taken so her daughter is pictured instead.

loans.use: To build a new house.

loans.name: Felix Liyayi

texts.en:
Felix L. is 37 years old from Shinyalu in Kakamega. He is married and has two children; Philip L. who is 18 years old and Josephine who is 15 years old.

Felix is a carpenter and has been doing this business for the past 13 years. He is applying for his first loan from us having been introduced to Kadet Ltd by a friend who is also a client. He intends to use the money to buy more timber to add to his business. His business is located along the road to Kakamega road.

His hope and dream is to open another carpentry business in Kakamega town.

loans.use: to buy timber

loans.name: Luzmila

texts.es: Luzmila, de 31 años, es una madre de familia que siempre ha luchado por salir adelante, vive en la casa de su suegra, junto a su esposo Fredy de 26 años y su querido hijo Bryan, a quien desea brindar unos buenos estudios. Los verdes campos del poblado de Huaracayo (Distrito de la provincia de Tarma), han sido en la vida de Luzmila un lugar muy agradable para trabajar, desde muy pequeña sus padres le enseñaron esta labor y ahora ella tiene sus propias tierras en las que trabaja con mucho esmero y sacrificio. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es cultivar arvejas y choclos, lleva 21 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es transportar sus cultivos, hasta el lugar donde los vende en el mercado de Tarma. Con el tiempo, espera poner un pequeño puesto en el mercado, ya que siente que pierde mucho al vender sus productos al por mayor. Este es el octavo crédito con MFP, sabe que tiene la responsabilidad de pagar todas sus cuotas puntualmente y está dispuesta a hacerlo. Dentro su banco comunal siempre esta al tanto de todos los acuerdos a los que llegan. Con los mil nuevos soles que solicita, comprará semillas de arveja, ya que esta planta leguminosa se esta vendiendo muy bien en el mercado.
texts.en:
Luzmila, 31 years old, is the mother of a family and has struggled always to get ahead. She lives in her mother-in-law's house with her husband Fredy, who is 26, and her dear son Bryan, to whom she wishes to offer a good education. The green fields of Huaracayo (a district of Tarma province) have always been a feature of Luzmila's life. This is a very agreeable place to work. Since she was very small, Luzmila's parents taught her farming skills and, now, she has her own lands in which she works with much care and sacrifice. What Luzmila likes most about her work is cultivating vetch and corn. She has been doing this for 21 years. What she considers most difficult is transporting her harvests to where she sells them, the market of Tarma. In time, she hopes to establish a small stall in the market, because she believes she loses much by selling them at wholesale. This is her 8th loan with MFP, and she understands the responsibility of making all her payments punctually which she is disposed to do. Within her communal bank she is always up to date on the agreements they arrive at. With the 1,000 new sols she requests Luzmila will buy vetch seeds, since this leguminous plant is selling very well in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING VETCH SEEDS TO SOW

loans.name: Mr. Lorng Seu Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has fifteen people who live in Kdei Ta Hok village in the Takeo province. They will use their portion of the loan for varied ways to support their family. 

Mr. Lorng S. is 54 years old. He's become the village bank president selected by the other members. He is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land in which to cultivate rice to sell to support his family; moreover, he is also a village chief. His wife, Mrs. Broeu Chev, owns a general store in the local village and she is breeding three pigs. 

His problem is that his wife’s pigs are too small to sell. So to improve breeding, Mr. Lorng S. is applying for a loan to buy pig food. He is a father of two children, one of whom is helping with the businesses, while the other is studying in the local village.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Chanhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanhorn S., and her husband, Mr. Lean Nau, live on an Island of the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2003 and have two young sons.

Chanhorn and her husband are weavers. They sell their finished products to the middle man in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. In addition to weaving, Mr. Lean was also hired by villagers to farm. He gets paid with fees, which he uses to support his family. Chanhorn has requested a Kiva loan before; she is now applying for another loan of $200 to purchase weaving materials for continuing her weaving business.

Chanhorn was not available for the picture, so her husband is pictured.

loans.use: To purchase cotton thread

loans.name: Maria Victoria

texts.es:
María es madre de cuatro hijos, trabajadora de 57 años de edad, mujer muy esforzada por apoyar  a su familia.
Hoy en día se dedica a trabajar en servicios domestico para ganarse el pan de cada día. Su mayor anhelo ha sido tener una vivienda en buenas condiciones de concreto, pero se le ha hecho difícil. Ya que su condición económica es de muy poco recursos.
Atreves del financiamiento ha venido comprando materiales de construcción en donde tiene: piedra, perlines, hierro. Poco a poco ha venido comprando ya que no ha podido comenzar por que su financiamiento es de poco, y no ha logrado los materiales completos para comenzar la obra.
Comprara: un quintal de hierro, cien bloques, ocho bolsa de cemento, un metro de arena y piedrín. Y comenzar. Contenta ya que lo está logrando, siendo Afodenic una puerta para lograr una mejor vivienda.
texts.en: María is a mother of four, a hardworking, courageous 57-year-old woman helping her family. She currently works in domestic services to earn her daily bread. Her main goal has been to have a concrete home in good condition, but this has been difficult since she has very few economic resources. With her finances, she has been buying construction materials like stone, beams, and iron. She has been shopping little by little with the small amount of money she has, as she has not been able to buy all the materials to start the work. She will buy 100 lbs of iron, 100 bricks, eight bags of cement, a meter of sand, and gravel, and she will begin the work. She is happy with what she has accomplished, with Afodenic being the door to a better home.

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to improve her concrete house and be able to enjoy a dignified home

loans.name: Sot

texts.en:
Mrs. Sot S. (pictured with her loom and her daughter), 40, and her husband, Mr. Sopha Bou, 39, have been married since 1993 and have one daughter. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Sot is a weaver. Mr. Sopha Bou sells silk and cotton products. He buys them from other weavers the village and some from his wife and sells to middleman who comes to buy them at his home.  

Sot is requesting her first loan of US$ 700 to purchase weaving materials for her weaving business and buy silk and cotton products for resale.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her weaving business and buy silk and cotton products for resale

loans.name: Ivan

texts.en:
Ivan is married with one teen-aged daughter.  He offers transportation services by taking passengers every day on a certain route.  His income is 4,000 Grivnas a month.

Ivan has been in the transportation business for 3 years.  He used to have a small store where he and his wife worked together.  Later his wife decided she would not sell alcohol and tobacco at the store.  Ultimately Ivan decided to sell the store and change the business.  

Ivan is requesting a loan of 13,000 Grivnas to fix the engine. The car broke and is not working at the moment. Ivan cannot make any income until he fixes the car.

loans.use: To fix car engine

loans.name: Djavid

texts.ru:
Djavid A. 24 qoda. On  molodoy ne jenatiy qrajdanin kotoriy yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda, seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste s semyoy. 
Djavid uje 2 qoda kak zanimayetsya lubimoy rabotoy skotovodstvom. Djavit ochen xochet uvelichit kolichestvo skota  poetomu on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit ovec. Djaviq s pomoshyu etoy sudu xochet uvelichit yejemeshechniy svoy doxod . Tak je v budushem imeya bolshe zarabotok on xochet jenitsya.
texts.en:
Djavid A. is twenty-four-years-old.  He's a young and single refugee from the city of Fuzili, who currently lives in the Fuzili region with his family.

Djavid has been doing his favorite job, raising cattle, for the past two years.  He really wants to get more cattle so he needs 2000 AZN to buy feed.  With the help he gets from the bank he wants to increase his monthly income because in the future, when he's earning more, he would like to get married.

loans.use: To buy feed.

loans.name: Warlito

texts.en:
Warlito A. lives in the village of Olango. He is 59 years old, married and has two grown children. For the last 40 years, he has made a living as a rice farmer and earns about 13,000 PHP a month from his work.

In 2008, Warlito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business. He has successfully repaid six previous loans from ASKI and has applied for a new one, for 45,000 PHP to buy fertilizer. He plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to support his family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for a rice crop

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea S. A., 48, is a construction foreman living in Takeo province with his wife and three children. Doing construction work, he is able to make about $5 US each day, while his wife works growing rice and vegetables. On average, she makes $1 US per day. This couple is also supported by one child who works in construction like the father. 

Chea S. A. is asking for a loan of $600 US to purchase a small tractor to plow the farmland and also to rent to other farmers who have no cow or small tractor to plow their land.

loans.use: To purchase a small tractor

loans.name: George Gathayo

texts.en:
George has been operating his motorcycle transport business in Naivasha town for the last two years.  He is 42 years old and is married to Damaris Njoki.  They have two children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend.  This will be his second loan.  George repaid his first loan of Kshs 10,000 well and in good time.  With this new loan, he plans to renew the insurance coverage for his motorcycle and to service it.

In the future, George hopes to own a taxi  to operate in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To renew insurance coverage and service motorcycle

loans.name: Monhtuya

texts.en:
Monhtuya, 33, is married and lives with her husband and two daughters in Bayanhongor Province of Mongolia. They live in a ger (Mongolian nomadic housing tent) which they bought four years ago along with the land. Her husband is her co-worker and sells clothing to the people in the countryside who are not able to reach the market everyday. 

They used to live in the countryside herding livestock before they came to the province center. She began her clothing trading business in 2007 by renting an outdoor stall at a local market. Now she rents a kiosk. She began her retail trading operation with working capital of 1,000,000 MNT and was able to increase it up to 4,000,000 MNT. She plans to diversify the variety of the goods and pays attention to its quality as people prefer higher quality products these days. She used to purchase her goods from Erlian, which is a city near the Chinese border. Now she prefers to bring clothing from Beijing, the capital of China, as there is more variety and higher quality clothing there. 

She is an open-minded and sociable person who says, "We want to make more profit and build our own house on the land we own now by next year." She is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to purchase more clothing for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida, 34 years old, is a married woman from the town of Surallah. Nida is a rice farmer and hog-grower. She cultivates her land for planting and harvesting rice farm. She rents a stall at the market to sell her harvest. Nida also raises pigs in her backyard. The pigs she grows are for fattening and sale. Nida works hard to be able to sustain her family.

Nida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nida has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Nida is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to buy piglets, feed and fertilizer. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy piglets, feed and fertilizer

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther N. is 22 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has one child.  Her child is currently in school.  Esther has a business selling raw food, which she has had for 5 years.         

To help expand her business, Esther has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more food for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Esther hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her child. 

 In the future, Esther hopes to own a plot of land. Esther is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by supporting her through giving her a loan to improve her business so she can be hard-working. That has changed her life.

loans.use: to purchase more food for resale

loans.name: Cecibel

texts.es:
Doña Cecibel, reside en El Divisadero departamento de Morazán, tiene 46 años de edad, se dedica a la venta de comida, antojitos, bisutería y ropa. Ella vive con su esposo don Maudo Antonio y un hijo Juan Antonio de 18 años de edad.
El negocio es una variedad de productos: comida (desayunos y almuerzos), por las tardes antojitos (enchiladas, pasteles), Ropa, Bisutería y artículos de uso personal como prendedores de cabello, cosméticos, esta diversidad de artículos lo tiene en su propia casa, por lo que  no tiene un horario fijo para atender a los clientes. Actualmente solicita un préstamo para comprar ropa, ya que desea aumentar el inventario teniendo diversidad de ropa.
Este préstamo le ayudara a cubrir esta parte del negocio y mantenerse en buenos niveles de inventario y ofrecer a los clientes  prendas de vestir a la moda y para todos los gustos; el sueño de doña Cecibel es hacer una casa en un terreno frente donde vive hoy, este sueño hace que ella permanezca con ánimos para continuar en el negocio y realizarlo dentro de poco tiempo.
texts.en:
Doña Cecibel resides in El Divisadero in the Department of Morazán. She is 46 years old and sells food, snacks, trinkets, and clothing. Cecibel lives with her husband Don Maudo Antonio and her 18 year old son Juan.

Her business includes a variety of products: food (breakfast and lunch), afternoon snacks (enchiladas and pastries), clothing, trinkets, and personal use items such as hairpins and cosmetics. She offers these different products from her home. Cecibel attends to her customers, but she does not work on a fixed schedule. At the moment, she is requesting a loan to buy clothes so that she can increase her inventory and offer more variety.

This loan will help cover part of her business and maintain her inventory at good levels. As a result, she will be able to offer her customers fashions for all tastes. Her dream is to build a store on the land in front of where she lives today. She is determined to continue with her business so she wants to pursue this goal very soon.

loans.use: To purchase clothing.

loans.name: Bosque De Las Flores Group

texts.es: El nombre de este grupo es BOSQUES DE LAS FLORES,  ya que sus integrantes  pertenecen a dos comunidades: Bosques de San Sebastian y Valle de las Flores, y al unirse como grupo fusionaron sus nombres, este grupo se localiza en Puebla, México. El grupo esta conformado por 10 integrantes y es la segunda vez que piden un prestamo. La señora DIANA T. T., es la Tesorera del grupo, estudio unicamente la preparatoria y es casada. Se dedica a la venta de zapatos. La señora es reconocida por sus compañeras por una persona responsable y que ha salido adelante ante la adversidad, el prestamo lo requiere para invertir más en su negocio y comprar por mayoreo ya que le hacen muchos pedidos y aveces no le alcanza para cumplir con todos los clientes a tiempo, quiere obtener mayor ganacia y hacer crecer su negocio con el fin de que más adelante pueda ofrecerles una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
This group is called 'Bosques de las Flores' because its members live in two communities: Bosques de San Sebastian and Valle de las Flores.  When they joined together as a group they also joined their names.  The group is located in Puebla, Mexico.  

This group has ten members and this is the second time that they have requested a loan.  Diana T. T. is the group's treasurer.  She has an elementary school level of education and is married.  Diana's business is selling shoes.  She is known by her fellow group members as being a responsible person who has managed to get ahead when faced with setbacks.  She needs this loan to further invest in her business and buy products wholesale since people are placing a lot of orders with her and sometimes she doesn't have enough to satisfy all her customers on time.  She would like to make more profits and grow her business so that, in the future, she can offer her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to invest in her footwear business

loans.name: San Jeronimo X Group

texts.es: El nombre de este grupo es SAN JERONIMO, en honor a su comunidad que se donomina del mismo nombre y se encuenta localizaco en Puebla, México. El grupo esta conformado por 9 integrantes y es su cuarta vez que solicita un prestamo. La señora MINERVA MARGARITA BERMUDES, es la Presidenta del grupo, ella tiene 31 años de edad, estudio unicamente la primaria, casada y tiene tres hijos (9,10 y15 años). Se dedica a la venta de zapato por catalogo; es conocida por sus compañeras por ser una persona responsable y que ha salido adelante ante la adversidad, siendo originaria de esta comunidad ha progresado. El prestamo lo requiere para comprar zapatos por mayoreo y asi obtener mas ganancias. Con las ganancias que obtenga lo utilizará para continuar brindandoles educación a sus hijos y una mejor vida, así como apoyo para los gastos familiares.
texts.en:
The name of this group is “San Jeronimo” in honor of the community of the same name, which is located in Puebla, Mexico. This group consists of nine members and is requesting a loan for the fourth time.

Sra. Minerva Margarita Bermudes is the group president. She is 31 years old and only has an elementary school education. Minerva is married and has three children (ages 9, 10, and 15). She sells shoes through catalogs and is known among her fellow group members for being a responsible person who presses forward despite adversity. Minerva is originally from this community and has made progress. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy shoes in bulk so that she can generate more earnings. The income that she earns will be used to continue providing education for her children, give them a better life, and help cover the family expenses.

loans.use: To purchase shoes in bulk.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace A. O. is 37 years old and single. She runs a salon to earn a living. She also sells second-hand clothes for extra income.  

Since she became a member of Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to save her money. This has helped her to manage her business finances.  

She has applied for a loan of 20,000 KES with her shares in Faulu Kenya. She plans to use the money to buy a hair dryer. She aspires to open a hair dressing college in the future.

loans.use: to buy a hair dryer.

loans.name: Memunatu

texts.en:
This is 46 year-old Memunatu. She is married and has four children aged 21, 19, 16, and nine. In 1996, Memunatu established her plastic bowls, buckets and other plastic-ware business. She began her business because her husband was sick and she had to take care of the family. She opens her business seven days a week and 10 hours a day. 

She would like a loan in the amount of 5,000,000 Sierra Leonean leones (SLL) to buy plastic bowls, buckets and other plastic utensils for her business. In the future, Memunatu plans to educate her children to the university level. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy plastic bowls, buckets, and other plastic utensils

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa is a 42-year-old married woman living in Trinidad, Bohol. She sells fish for a living. Her husband is a fisherman, and she is the one who sells all his catch at the market. Marissa also buys and resells seafood such as crabs and prawns.

Marissa is asking a loan to buy fishing nets, hooks and other fishing gears. She will also buy more seafood to resell. The loan will help Marissa continue her fishing business.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets, hooks and other fishing gears

loans.name: Ventatie

texts.en: Ventatie   is 29 years old, and she has a one-year-old child. She owns a shop in which she sells rice and soap. This business has enabled her to feed her family. She has done this business for the past two years. She needs a loan to buy foodstuffs and make more profits. She plans to save all her profits and buy a milling machine.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs.

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en:
Ramatu is 45 years old and married with 3 children between the ages of 23 and 29. She runs a general merchant store in Grassfield, a neighborhood of Freetown.

Ramatu has been in this business for 10 years and sells provisions and building materials at her store. She also earns income from renting a house. She says that the main challenge to her business is price control (inflation).

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more business commodities. Ramatu says that the extra income from this loan will help her improve the standard of living for her family. In the future, she would like to be a supplier to other business partners.

loans.use: to purchase more business commodities.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn works hard to support her family. Evelyn is married and has a sari-sari (convenience) store business in the Philippines.

Evelyn requested a 25,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell like soft-drinks, curls (puffed cheese-flavored snacks), bread and other miscellaneous items.  Evelyn has been in this business for 16 years.

Evelyn would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell like soft-drinks, curls, bread and other miscellaneous item

loans.name: Julio Alberto

texts.es: Julio Alberto, tiene la edad de 46 años, está casada, vive con sus 3 hijos y su esposa que son su mayor prioridad. El pretende con el crédito realizar la compra de los insumos para la asistencia de su cafetal. El cuenta con el terreno apto y en buenas condiciones para la explotación de café, el terreno está sembrado y en producción años atrás. El quiere darle a su cafetal una ayuda con el  abono y limpiarlo de las plagas para así este año tener mayores producciones de café, generando así ganancias para su bienestar familiar. Es el primer  préstamo que  recibido de FUDECOSUR. El no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en: Julio Alberto is 46-years-old, married, and lives with his wife and three children who are his top priority.  He plans to use the loan to purchase agricultural additives for his coffee plantation.  He has a land parcel that is ready and in good condition for growing coffee.  He has seeded the land and it has been used for coffee production in past years.  He would like to help the land produce with fertilizer and remove pests so that it can produce more coffee which will lead to greater profits for his family’s well-being.  This is his first loan from FUDECOSUR.  They have given him this loan with greater ease and the interest rate is much lower.

loans.use: to grow coffee.

loans.name: Setuka Wobadde Development Group

texts.en:
37-year-old John Baptist's reckoning is that this Kiva loan will come in invaluably handy for the expansion of his food sales business in the town of Mityana. He mostly sells high favor foods such as bananas, coffee, maize, cassava, sweet potatoes, etc in food markets in Mityana. To steer clear of failure the last six years he has been doing this business, John has been employing fundamental principals like relentless diligence, thinking outside the box and constant planning. These in tandem with a good working relationship with his clients, have been the hallmarks of his business' success. 
John, who on the face of it is a buoyant and hospitable father of eight, says he began this business to avoid a situation where he had to live by his wits.
The business grew more with persuasion and a pep talk from close friends and relatives. Monthly, he says, his sales income totals up to Ugandan shillings 420,000. John says he is requesting this Kiva loan to purchase more bags of maize and coffee to sell.

loans.use: to purchase more bags of maize and coffee to sell

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida is 62 years old and married with 5 children. Adelaida works very hard to provide for them.

Adelaida runs a sari sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell.

Adelaida has been in this business for 5 years and sells a variety of items such as noodles, canned goods, sugar, biscuits, shampoo, etc. 

In the future Adelaida would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell

loans.name: Tuzamurane Rsz Group

texts.fr:
Jean de Dieu est commerçant  et il est membre du groupe Tuzamurane. Il est né au Rwanda et a 45 ans. Il est marié et il a 6 enfants de 1 à 11 ans, dont 3 scolarisés. Son niveau d’éducation est 8 ans de primaire. 
C’est son premier cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit pour acheter des riz, des haricots, des caisses des fantas (boisson non alcooliser)vendre dans son boutique. 
Sa stratégie pour la croissance de son business est d’augmenter la capacité de son business en achetant d’autre beaucoup des marchandises pour satisfaire le marché. Dans les prochaines années, Jean voudrait être un grand commerçant, et distributeur des marchandises. Avec les profits, Il voudrait  payer les frais des études pour ses enfants.
texts.en:
Jean de Dieu is a shopkeeper and a member of the group Tuzamurane. He was born in Rwanda and is 45 years old. He is married and has six children, from 1 to 11 years old. Three of the children are in school. He has an 8th grade education. 

This loan cycle is his first one with ACB. He is going to use his loan to buy rice, beans, and cases of Fanta (a softdrink) to sell in his shop. His strategy for business growth is to increase his business capacity by buying much more merchandise to satisfy the market. 

In the next few years, Jean would like to be a major merchant and to distribute merchandise. With the profits, he would like to cover the cost of schooling for his children.

loans.use: to buy rice, beans, cases of Fanta (softdrink) to sell in his shop

loans.name: Delia

texts.en: Delia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a tailoring business in the Philippines. She is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 from Kiva's partner, NWTF, to purchase additional materials for her tailoring shop. Delia has been in this business for 30 years. Delia earns additional income from a tricycle transport business. She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials for her tailoring shop

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 51 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children.

Jocelyn has a retail shop that buys and sells rice grains by the kilogram. She has had this business for 20 years.  She has requested a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy more rice for resale.

Jocelyn is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy rice for resale

loans.name: Dushyigikirane Mgz Group

texts.fr:
Joseph  fait partie du groupe Dushyigikirane. Le nom du groupe signifie « Help each other ». Il a 47 ans et il est marié avec 8 enfants de 3 à 21 ans, dont 4scolarisés. Son niveau d’éducation est  6 ans de primaire.

Joseph est cultivateur de riz. C’est son premier cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit afin d’acheter des engrais chimiques pour son agriculture de riz. 

Sa stratégie pour la croissance de son business est de faire la semence sélectionnée du riz et utilisation des fertilisants. Dans les prochaines années, Joseph voudrait être parmi les meilleurs fournisseurs de riz dans sa région. Avec les profits, il prévoit d’éduquer ses enfants.
texts.en:
Joseph is a member of the Dushyigikirane group. The group's name means "Help Each Other". Joseph is 47 years old and married with eight children aged 3 to 21. Four of them go to school. He himself attended six years of primary school.

Joseph is rice farmer. This is his first loan cycle with ACB. He will use the credit to buy fertilizers.

His business growth strategy is to be discerning in the rice seed to plant, and to use fertilizers. In the coming years, Joseph wants to become one of the leading rice suppliers in the area. He will use his profits to support his children’s education.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for his rice farming activity

loans.name: Francisco Antonio

texts.es:
Francisco tiene 59 años de edad, es casado y vive con su esposa, su nuera y su nieto.

Francisco se dedica a la agricultura desde muy pequeño, ocupación que aprendió de su padre. Francisco cultiva maíz en un terreno cerca de su casa. Él ha solicitado un préstamo a Fundación Campo para la compra de insumos agrícolas como fertilizantes, fungicidas y herbicidas. Con la ayuda del préstamo Francisco podrá tener una mejor cosecha, y así obtener mejores ingresos.

En el futuro Francisco planea rentar un terreno para cultivo el cual es de su propriedad, y poder tener otra fuente de ingresos.
texts.en:
Francisco, 59, is married and lives with his wife, daughter-in-law and grandson.

Francisco has been involved in agriculture since he was very young and learned it from his father.  He grows corn on land near his home.  He has requested a loan through Fundación Campo to buy agriculture supplies such as fertilizer, fungicides and herbicides.  With the help of the loan Francisco can obtain a better crop and more income.

In the future he would like to rent out some of his land so he can have another source of income.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, fungicides and herbicides for his corn crop.

loans.name: Diana

texts.es: Diana es una mujer de 46 años de edad, divorciada hace un año atrás. Tiene 4 hijos de los cuales solo vive con 1 y sus 2 nietos, en una casa propia en la comunidad nativa de Pucharini. Diana comenta que su negocio consiste en la compra y venta de ropa. Dicha mercadería lo adquiere por mayor en las galerías de “Gamarra”, en la ciudad de Lima, una vez comprado, viaja hacia las comunidades nativas de Pichanaki y las vende, para ello, ya tiene clientes que le hacen pedidos con anticipación, por esa seguridad siempre tiene compradores fieles. Al mismo tiempo, pero en menor proporción, se dedica a las labores del campo sembrando plátanos, palta, café y frutas cítricas. Asegura que, la venta de ropa siempre ha sido rentable, con tal de captar clientes fijos. “Cuando hay días buenos mi inversión de 1000 soles, se triplica”, dice emocionada. En cuanto a los problemas que tuvo que superar, Diana menciona a la falta de capital como principal, con el tiempo y gracias a su inagotable labor, ésta emprendedora mujer piensa abrir una tienda de abarrotes para no tener que estar viajando demasiado. Con su apoyo, ella podrá obtener su préstamo número 4 de MFP, entidad de la cual se siente agradecida y comprometida a pagar con esfuerzo y puntualidad. Diana, a la vez se siente contenta trabajando con su banco comunal por que algunos de sus integrantes también se dedican a su rubro. Una vez obtenido el crédito, ella viajará a la ciudad de Lima para invertir los 2000 soles en la compra de ropa, pues ya tiene clientes asegurados para la campaña de diciembre y enero.
texts.en: Diana is 46 years old and got divorced a year ago. She has four children, of which only one lives with her along with two grandchildren in a home she owns in the native community of Pucharini. Diana says her business consists of buying and selling clothing. She acquires her merchandise at wholesale from the "Gamarra" center in the city of Lima. Once purchased, she travels through the native communities of Pichanaki and sell the items, since she has customers there who make orders in advance, so she has the security of always having faithful buyers. At the same time, although at a smaller scale, she works in the fields harvesting bananas, avocado, coffee and citrus fruits.
